channel.title: BBC News - Africa
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Somali feminist: Facebook is being used to silence me
item.description: Hanna Paranta has faced assassination attempts and now online attacks for helping abused women.

item.title: World Cup: Penalty given after five seconds sparks Tanzania win
item.description: Tanzania beat Madagascar 3-2 after needing just five seconds to earn a penalty, as Libya leapfrog Egypt.

item.title: Diamond League Final: Francine Niyonsaba says 'I'm back to make sport better'
item.description: Francine Niyonsaba says she keeps competing after her enforced switch to longer distances to "make sport a better place and inspire others".

item.title: Guinea coup: Are military takeovers on the rise in Africa?
item.description: Despite a series of coups in Africa over the past few months, the longer trend down is downward.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: TPLF says 150 have died of starvation
item.description: There is a "complete depletion of food stocks" in the Ethiopian region of Tigray, the TPLF says.

item.title: Guinea opposition leader backs coup against Alpha CondÃ©
item.description: Cellou Dalein Diallo says Sunday's takeover "completes" the work that opposition groups had begun.

item.title: Morocco elections: What's the one thing voters would change?
item.description: Ahead of the 8 September elections, we asked young people in Casablanca what it's like to be Moroccan in 2021.

item.title: The South African farm turning flies into food for pets - and maybe people
item.description: A South African company is aiming to take advantage of a new interest in protein-rich insects.

item.title: Guinea coup: Who is Col Mamady Doumbouya?
item.description: Little is known about the early life of Col Mamady Doumbouya, a former soldier in the French army.

item.title: South Africa danger zone: Living in a 'hijacked' building
item.description: Pictures of squatters in a South African inner city with high levels of crime, drugs and prostitution.

item.title: Kenyan men join battle to end FGM
item.description: Campaigners say it is important that Kenyan men join the battle to end female genital mutilation.

item.title: Sahel jihadists: West Africa faces up to policing its terror triangle
item.description: New tactics are being used in the fight against jihadists as Chad and France reduce their military roles.

item.title: Nigerian students amass degrees to stay in Europe
item.description: Modupe Osunkoya enrolled on her third post-graduate degree because she says there are no jobs at home.

item.title: Ethiopia's economy battered by Tigray war
item.description: Food prices are rising, the currency's value is falling and investor confidence is shaken.

item.title: Guinea coup: What has been the regional reaction to the coup?
item.description: Ecowas has condemned the coup in Guinea threatening with sanctions unless the president is released.

item.title: Jah Prayzah: 'Mbira is part of Zimbabwean culture'
item.description: Zimbabwean musician Jah Prayzah maintains his passion for traditional music despite being an Afrobeats star.

item.title: The ATMs that dispense green fuel
item.description: How a start-up in Kenya is changing the way people cook.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Ntando Mahlangu describes how blades changed his life
item.description: How Ntando Mahlangu's prosthetic blades changed his life and led him to two golds at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Paracycling: 'How handcycling helped me rebuild my life'
item.description: Macoumba Toure Sarr has been using handcycling to rebuild his life following a devastating accident.

item.title: Zambian President Hichilema: Corruption at 'horrifying' levels
item.description: Corruption is at "horrifying" levels, Hakainde Hichilema tells the BBC, a week after being sworn in.

item.title: Strictly: Why are South African dancers so popular?
item.description: As Strictly prepares to return to our screens next month another South African dancer has joined the professionals.
